MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cúram na Gaeilge.
MainHeading.P: 1. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: den Taoiseach an bhfuil sé sásta leis an tslí ina bhfuil cúram na Gaeilge roinnte amach ar na hAirí go léir; agus an measann sé gur fearr don teanga é Aire amháin a chur i gceannas ar leathadh na Gaeilge i ngach gné de shaol na tíre.

Speaker.hpid: An Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Ní chun leas na teanga a rachadh sé dá mbeifí le freagracht iomlán. i leith na Gaeilge a chur ar aon Aire amháin. Fiú ó thaobh na praiticiúlachta de, ní dóigh liom go mbeadh sé indéanta na cúraimí atá ag an Aire Oideachais i leith na Gaeilge, mar shampla, a aistriú go dtí Aire na Gaeltachta. Is fearr i bhfad ó thaobh na teanga de, go mbeadh freagrachtaí i leith na Gaeilge ar Airí éagsúla ina réimsí oibre féin.

Tá freagrachtaí faoi leith ag Aire na Gaeltachta faoi alt 3 den Acht Airí agus Rúnaithe (Leasú) 1956, ina measc dul i gcomhairle, sa mhéid is gá nó is cuí, le Ranna eile Stáit chun leas na Gaeltachta agus na teanga a chur chun cinn. Táim sásta go gcomhlíonann Aire na Gaeltachta an dualgas atá air faoin bhforáil sin.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Chuala mé an chuid is mó de fhreagra an Taoisigh ach tá roinnt de nár chuala mé i gceart. An dtuigeann sé na deacrachtaí atá againn ceisteanna a chur síos faoi chursaí Gaeilge nuair nach bhfuil aon Aire freagrach anseo, mar a fuair mé amach nuair a chuir mé ceist síos do Aire na Gaeltachta faoi chláracha Gaeilge in RTE? Bhí orm an cheist a chur don Aire Cumarsáide, ach dúirt seisean nach raibh sé freagrach, gurb iad RTE a bhí freagrach agus atá freagrach. Tá me ag fiafraigh den Taoiseach nach mbeadh sé i bhfad níos fearr dá mbeadh fiú amháin Aire Stáit freagrach? D'fhéadfainn ansin ceisteanna a chur ar an Aire sin agus gheobhadh seisean an freagra amach ó Roinn, nó ó Roinn Stáit nó ón Chomhlacht Stáit a bheadh i mbun an ruda sin. Ní féidir linn é sin a dhéanamh faoi láthair.

Speaker.hpid: An Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Tuigim na deacrachtaí atá ann, ach mar a dúirt me im fhreagra, is féidir le Teachtaí a gcuid ceisteanna a chur chuig an Aire atá freagrach san Roinn atá i gceist.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Sin díreach an deacracht. Cad is féidir liom a dhéanamh mar gheall ar na cláracha Gaeilge atá ag RTE, abair? Níl aon Aire freagrach faoi cheist mar sin, mar a fuair mé amach — agus is féidir leis an Ceann Comhairle aontú liom mar tá litir agam anseo uaidh ag rá sin.

Speaker.hpid: An Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: D'fhéadfadh an Teachta an cheist a chur ar an Aire Cumarsáide. Tá sé mar aidhm ag RTE ar feadh tréimhse ceithre bliana go mbeadh 20 faoin gcéad dá gcláracha sa Ghaeilge, agus tá cláracha faoi leith do pháistí.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Níor thug mé ach sampla amháin, agus fuair mé an freagra ón Aire Cumarsáide nach bhfuil aon fhreagracht oifigiúil ag an Aire Cumarsáide mar is gnó do chuid RTE féin é. Níl Aire na Gaeltachta freagrach as chúrsaí Gaeilge taobh amuigh den Ghaeltacht. Uair amháin ba é an tAire Oideachais a bhí i gceannas cúrsaí na Gaeilge: uair amháin bhíodh an tAire Oideachais i gceannas cúrsaí Gaeilge ar fad sa tír. Anois, an bhfuil aon Aire ar féidir linn ceist a chur air? Tá cúram ag an Stát faoi seo, tá cúram ag an Rialtas faoi ach níl aon Aire nó Aire Stáit, fiú amháin——

Speaker.hpid: An Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Tá an deacracht céanna faoi a lán ábhar eile.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Nach n-aontódh an Taoiseach liom, muna mbíonn an spiorad ceart, agus an aidhm agus an tsuim ag lucht RTE, gur beag is féidir le haon Aire a dhéanamh faoi chláracha Gaeilge RTE?

Speaker.hpid: An Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Sin ceist eile.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is prepared to increase the headage payments this year as a once-off measure to help farmers affected by the bad weather earlier this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Substantial Exchequer funds have been made available for various measures to assist farmers who have been affected by the bad weather. These measures include the winter fodder scheme, the Shannon Valley flood scheme and the feed voucher scheme. It is not possible to provide further Exchequer funds to finance an increase in headage payments.

As regards a suggestion put forward by one of the farming organisations for financing such an increase, I indicated in the Dáil on 6 November that I was keeping this under review in the light of budgetary constraints and the Estimates which are being drawn up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): I should like to draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the maximum amount allowed under EC regulations in respect of the headage grant is not being paid here. Because of the exceptional circumstances on this occasion following the disastrous weather conditions during the summer, would the Minister consider, as a once-off measure and by way of alleviating the serious problems of the farmers, and of enabling them to have adequate cash flows, making the maximum amounts available?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: We never did pay the maximum headage grants allowable. In reply to the second part of the supplementary, the answer is no and that is for the same reason as the reason outlined in the original reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that if he backed up by the same amount the £17 million available in Europe for extending the headage payments, the net cost to the Exchequer would be offset by the direct cash input that would be made available throughout the country by way of that £17 million from Europe?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I am not convinced of that argument and as I have pointed out previously, I am not enamoured of the equity of the scheme being suggested by Opposition Deputies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Is the Minister acknowledging that the money is available?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Yes, and it has been available since our accession to the EC but we have never used it to the maximum.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 4.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): When is the Minister likely to make a decision with regard to the very generous offer that has been made by the farming organisations?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: As I have said, the matter is being examined in the light of budgetary constraints and also in terms of the Estimates that are being drawn up.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - Western Development Package.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McCartin Mr. McCartin
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware that only IR£20 million has been spent on the western development package; and if he proposes any alteration to the scheme which could result in a more efficient utilisation of the funds within the proposed period.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture (Mr. Connaughton) Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture (Mr. Connaughton)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture (Mr. Connaughton)
Speaker.P: Apart from aid for projects related to the processing and marketing of agricultural products, the total expenditure to 30 September 1985 under the western package is about £69 million.

MainHeading.P: The package operates by way of a programme approved by the EC Commission and this programme is subject to review at intervals of four years. The first such review is at present under way and an examination is being made of the options available for making the package a more effective instrument for the stimulation of agricultural development in the west.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that that scheme which was supposed to have been £30 million per year has been a flop and that under some of the headings there has been practically no takeup? Would he agree also that the conditions under which the scheme operated were such as to render it practically impossible for people to qualify?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware, certain restrictions were imposed on the package at the time but there are certain headings under which we are ahead of schedule. Though we are only four years on, the greater part of the ten year allocation for rural water supplies has been taken up. I take it that the Deputy is referring to such items as forestry in respect of which less than £1 million of the £18 million earmarked has been taken up. It is against that background that the matter is being reviewed currently. The review is at a very advanced stage and we hope that some of the problems can be rectified as far as possible from an Irish point of view.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not agree that it was ridiculous so far as a severely handicapped area was concerned to impose the kind of restrictions that were imposed regarding qualification for the scheme? Is it not time that those restrictions were lifted?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy MacSharry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not consider——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I have called Deputy MacSharry. Deputies should heed the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: ——that in regard to forestry he should have the whole matter reviewed so that the scheme could be extended beyond the western package to include areas outside the 12 counties to which the scheme relates?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton
Speaker.P: Matters relating to forestry are the responsibility of another Minister but I assume that in the context of the package, forestry is one of the areas being considered.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I cannot let pass what has happened. Deputies should not defy the Chair. The Chair cannot permit that sort of conduct.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: It was not my intention to be derogatory or insulting towards the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: But the Deputy continued regardless of what the Chair said.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: The Minister tells us that the review is almost completed but can he inform us whether there is included in that review any new measures or are only the existing measures included? Will the Minister make every effort to ensure that in particular the calf and beef schemes of the package are implemented?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton
Speaker.P: I cannot prejudge the outcome of the deliberations in Brussels. I can only tell the Deputy that I have taken great care to consider the weak points of the scheme and we hope that many of the matters to which the Deputy has referred will be put right in the new package.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This must be a final supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): Can the Minister guarantee that there will be Exchequer funds to finance the scheme on the completion of the review and the negotiations?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton
Speaker.P: I have no doubt that once the programme has been accepted, the Government will not be found wanting.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): In other words, the answer is yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Regarding the Minister's statement that after only four years we have spent the greater part of the allocation in respect of group water schemes, can he confirm that grants will be available for such schemes in the west for a further six years?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton
Speaker.P: I do not wish to prejudge the outcome of anything that might be under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Can the Minister confirm whether the money will be available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is well aware, the matter is not as simple as that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The matter relates to another Minister. The Minister of State made only a passing reference to these schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: But a passing question should elicit some information. There is no commitment.

MainHeading.RHead: Answers. - EC Beef and Dairy Mountains
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - EC Beef and Dairy Mountains.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the value of the beef and dairy mountains currently being held by the EC; if he will be presenting any proposals to the EC to dispose of them; and the proportions of Irish beef and dairy products that were sold into intervention in 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: The estimated value of the intervention stocks of beef and dairy products held by the Community at the end of October was about £4,200 million.

MainHeading.P: The disposal of intervention stocks is within the competence of the Commission. I have however, pressed consistently for an extension of the range of disposal measures on both internal and external markets. For example, a new measure which I have actively pursued for the sale of concentrated butter for cooking and baking was introduced recently by the Commission, and I understand that further disposal measures are under consideration. I have also pressed for measures to maximise sales on the commercial market and so reduce intervention intake.
So far this year 16 per cent of Irish production of beef and 44 per cent of production of butter have been sold into intervention.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): Would the Minister comment on a recent suggestion that some of the stock in intervention should be disposed of to third countries and that that would be a self-financing operation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Very little of the stock is suitable for the type of use the Deputy may have in mind. There is also the added element that however low the price got for the disposal of this stock, it is a very important source of finance to keep the Community going. As long as we can get a reasonable price for it, there is much to be said for selling it on the open market.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): The storage costs are so excessive that it would eliminate storage costs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Storage costs would be only a fraction of the price fetched when the stocks are disposed of.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Deputy Leonard, Deputy MacSharry and then Deputy Mac Giolla.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not agree that over the years many of the co-operatives and meat plants took the easy way out — they did not sell their produce but put it into intervention?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I could not agree more. For the past three years I have been advocating — and I am sure previous Ministers for Agriculture had been doing likewise — that people should not use intervention as a safety net but should be selling on the open market because that is where the profits are to be made. Putting this produce into intervention places a terrible burden on the funding of the EC.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Does the Minister intend taking any initiative to release some of the stocks in intervention to the processing industry. Particularly the hamburger factories?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: As regards the hamburger industry and processed meats, we rely a lot on third countries for that type of processing. These products can be purchased considerably cheaper abroad than they can be produced within the Community.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: We never imported these products from third countries before.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: This has been done for years. As long as I have been on the Council of Ministers these products have been imported. As regards milk products, we are using a lot of butter for cooking and baking purposes; that is one way of getting rid of it. The present Commissioner is very active in his efforts to get rid of as much stock as possible. Stocks are at a very high level, first, because of the continued increase in milk production up to last year and, second, as a result of the culling of cows which has increased the beef mountain.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: The Minister indicated that most of these stocks are unsuited for famine relief. Is he saying that these stocks have deteriorated and are unfit for human consumption?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Obviously a great deal of this beef would be suitable for you or for me but the food requirements vary from country to country and often times it can do a lot more harm than good. We have to be very careful what products we feed these people.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mayo Flood Damage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if a survey has been carried out in relation to flood damage in County Mayo; and if he will make funds available immediately to compensate for the serious damage caused.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if, in view of the serious problems facing the farming community in County Mayo because of recent flooding, he will ensure that adequate provision is made by the Government to compensate these farmers for their losses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 6 and 35 together. Due to the limited Exchequer resources available, assistance for flood damage victims had necessarily to be confined to farmers in areas of the Shannon Valley most severely affected by flooding. However, farmers in County Mayo and in other parts of the country who have been unable to conserve adequate winter fodder for their livestock were in a position to benefit from the winter fodder scheme 1985 and also eligible for the feed voucher scheme, details of which were announced earlier this month and which is due to close tomorrow.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: The Minister mentioned the Shannon area, and we are not objecting to help being given there, but there are areas in Mayo and elsewhere where land is covered by sand, bog and grit of all sorts. When the Shannon subsides at least the farmers will have land but in many instances the farmers in Mayo will have no land left and they can get no help by way of grant to get their land back into production. The Government should alleviate the problem of these small farmers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: My attention has not been drawn to any particular difficulty in Mayo which is not apparent elsewhere. If there was an area which might have been included it is that area adjacent to Dowra, County Cavan, where there was flooding of a nature which might have merited aid. That was not included because it came to light after we had decided on the areas to be included in the relief for the Shannon Valley. During the past summer and early autumn everyone had trouble as regards flooding, but unless there was something exceptional about the degree of flooding, we did not even examine the question of making relief available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten
Speaker.P: Would the Minister consider a further extension of the closing date for applications for relief?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: As much as I would like to do that, the fact is that by extending the date I would run into difficulties issuing the vouchers. I cannot start issuing vouchers until I know the total number of applicants. The sooner I know that the sooner I can get the scheme working. The original closing date was 20 November and it has now been extended to 27 November. I want to ensure that people get these feed vouchers as quickly as possible. Therefore, I do not think it fair to ask for a further extension because the week's extension is sufficient.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: When will the vouchers be issued?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: As quickly as possible. I hope in a matter of weeks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten
Speaker.P: Could the Minister tell the House approximately the number of applications he has received under the feed voucher scheme to date?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I could give a guesstimate, but not all the people who applied will be deemed eligible, although I hope they will. Obviously a certain percentage will probably be disqualified for various reasons, such as income level and so on. The latest figure is approximately 60,000.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Do I take it from the Minister's reply that if it is possible to make a case that land in Mayo has been destroyed because of flooding, he would be prepared to receive representations and would be disposed to give some help?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: As much as I sympathise with the Deputy, I would not like to give him false hope because I might have to look at many similar areas. I have an additional problem: we allocated £2.5 million for the winter fodder scheme on 8 August. One million pounds of that was for fertiliser and £1.5 million was allocated for first time silage makers. We estimated that the maximum number of people who would avail of the first time silage making scheme was 8,000. It transpired that something like 30,000 have availed of that scheme. As a result our estimate has gone through the roof. Instead of spending £1.5 million, we will spend something like £6 million. It is proving extremely difficult to find that extra money and, therefore, it will be extremely difficult to find additional money for cases similar to that mentioned by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten
Speaker.P: This proves it is a very good scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that there are about 30,000 people availing of that scheme, will the Minister increase the number of inspectors so that they can deal with these applications as quickly as possible? When does he envisage payment will be made?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: We have diverted every available resource to working on these emergency schemes. As regards payment, I cannot tell the Deputy at the moment. All I can say is that payments to the Shannon Valley have already commenced.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Deputy N. Treacy and then moving to the next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: As a result of the Minister's replies, particularly having regard to the large take-up on the first time silage making, will the Minister give a commitment that he will make a good grant available for the provision of silage plants in 1986?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is another question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: That question has been put down by Deputy Hilliard. I will answer it if we reach it today.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: A Cheann Comhairle——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am moving on to the next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: It is important.

Speaker.hpid: An Cheann Comhairle An Cheann Comhairle
Speaker.P: Everybody thinks the question he intends to ask is important.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: The people in ACOT informed me yesterday that the number of people they can visit in any one day is 15——

Speaker.hpid: An Cheann Comhairle An Cheann Comhairle
Speaker.P: That is not a question, whatever else it is.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: It is a question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 7.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the criteria for payment to farmers from his Department to alleviate losses incurred because of the very serious flooding.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Assistance to farmers who faced serious winter fodder problems as a result of flood damage is confined to people farming in parts of specific district electoral divisions in the Shannon valley area. The scheme is limited to those mainly dependent on farming with not more than 60 livestock units who have suffered fodder or, in some cases, crop losses. The maximum subsidy is £500 per farmer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give a reason why the Dunkellin river basin was not included in that scheme?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I cannot. I can only depend on the technical people in my Department who studied the question at first hand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say why the people living in the south eastern part of Galway north of Portumna right across to Woodford and into Ballycrosaun were not looked after?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: James J. Fitzpatrick used to do this travelogue once a week in the films but I cannot travel around the country giving a run down——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Liam Naughten.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten
Speaker.P: I am delighted at the way in which the scheme is operating but is there a possibility of giving special assistance to farmers in that area which is classified under the Shannon valley and the Suck valley aid scheme by way of an additional grant?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: We did not get an answer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: The reply to Deputy Naughten's question is the same as the reply I gave to Deputy Gallagher. I would love to have the resources but because of the overspending on the silage scheme it is proving particularly difficult to make additional areas qualify for the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy J. Leonard, and then I am moving on to the next question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - Creamery Milk Quotas.

Speaker.P: Approximately 1,800 eligible new entrants applied for additional quotas out of the special reserve I set up some months ago.

These are now being processed and all purchasers will be notified of their allocations over the next few days.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: Has the Minister checked out the bona fides of the 1,800 new entrants? It is quite late to be setting out quotas with three-quarters of the quota here gone. Will the Minister give an assurance that individual creameries will get their quotas straight away to allow them advise individual suppliers?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I share the Deputy's concern that people have been left waiting so long due to some creameries being very slow in making returns. Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I would ask Deputies to keep their questions short.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Would the Minister consider giving a quota to the farmers who participated in a non-marketing of the milk scheme? They did so in the belief that when the time expired they could go back into milk production.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I cannot hold out much hope for those people. My clinics are crowded with people with super-levy problems of one kind or another including that, but there is a list of priorities and the first few groups on the list will obviously absorb whatever milk there is through the cessation scheme or through flexi-milk. People as far down the list of priorities as those mentioned by the Deputy do not stand much of a chance as things stand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that there are proposals in the EC Commission for a voluntary cessation scheme, has the Minister any proposals to bring about a scheme here whereby we could make available extra quotas to young new entrants into the dairy industry?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: That is one of the priority questions on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: I cannot ask anything on that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: It would be unfair to the people who put down the question to answer it now.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - Meath Land Purchase.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteann—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bacon Industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Ahern Mr. M. Ahern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture his proposals for the restructuring and modernisation of the Irish bacon industry; if he will make a statement on the present slaughter capacity; and if he will give details of the capacity of each plant, especially the number of plants which have capacity to kill in excess of 5,000 per week.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: While our pigmeat export factories have an annual capacity of about 2½ million pigs, they are currently operating at around 70 per cent of this capacity. Details of individual plant capacity are confidential but I can say that only three plants have a capacity in excess of 5,000 pigs per week.

It is clear that there is a need for rationalisation and modernisation within the industry if it is to compete more effectively, particularly on export markets. For this reason a central pig slaughtering policy has been adopted under which it is intended to have at least six central slaughtering units, and maybe as many as ten, each capable of slaughtering 6,000 pigs per week, to cater for its own needs and, on a contract basis, for the needs of neighbouring processors. Generous grant aid is available from the IDA and FEOGA to suitable applicants who wish to participate in this programme. As well as reducing slaughtering costs and facilitating greater concentration of value-added processing, these central units will meet the standards of the US and other countries, thereby enabling traders to gain access to those export markets closed to them at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: Has the Minister any suggestion to make about the geographical position in which he recommends that those units should be sited? Is he going to allow a similar position to that which happened in the dairy industry when we had milk travelling all over the country? Now we see pigs travelling from Wexford to Tralee, in County Kerry. That is not in the interest of the industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: The IDA in conjunction with my Department — primarily the IDA — are promoting this new concept that we should have at least six and maybe ten large pig slaughtering units, and of course they are taking geographical locations into consideration. I am glad to say that there are three or four firm inquiries — indeed, more than inquiries — three or four groups or individuals interested in the IDA's proposal and I hope to see at least two of those commence in 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: In this modernisation scheme to which the Minister has referred, would he like to tell the House if the Claremorris bacon factory is one of the units which came under consideration for this, or had he an opportunity of interesting himself in what is happening there in relation to the imminent closure of the factory? If not, will he take steps to ensure that this factory is kept open in the interests of the farmers and the workers of the area?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I cannot give confidential information as to which groups are interested but I believe steps are afoot to try to resolve the problem that exists. I would not like to upset any moves being made by making any comment here today, but I am hopeful. I would be very concerned if the project did not continue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: The Minister said that five to six units would service the country. It is very important that the geographical location of those units would cater for the pigs so that we would not have trafficking at high transport costs. As it stands it seems as if they will all be in the one area.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Has the Deputy a question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: As it stands at the minute——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I do not think he has.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: Would the Minister use his good offices and the offices of his Department to advise? It is right to say that we are trying to model our bacon industry on the Danish industry.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: It is very relevant.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Maybe it is a grand speech. I will not go into the merits or otherwise of that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: A different pattern of units for a heavy concentration of pigs in an island country would be desirable.

MainHeading.P: The Minister should have a good look at the situation because it seems that we are going into very serious difficulties, similar to what the dairy industry went into six or seven years ago in the amalgamation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I said six units and maybe as many as ten, not five or six. I think the geographical spread will be quite satisfactory. The interests I am aware of who are thinking seriously about setting up these units are spread rather uniformly throughout the country so I am not worried about that aspect.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the further measures he intends to take to ensure that farmers will have sufficient feeding for their stock; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I have announced a series of measures over the past few months to alleviate feed problems faced by farmers as a result of the poor summer weather conditions. Apart from possible limited aid for cereal growers I do not envisage further measures at the moment.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not consider some low interest finance for farmers who find themselves in difficulty as a result of the bad weather this summer?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: Not for people who have difficulty with fodder. I have done as much as I intend to do on the fodder question, unless some catastrophic problems arise in winter or early spring. All things being equal, I have done as much as I intend to do at the moment. In relation to a later question also, I am considering at the moment some measures for tillage farmers, particularly cereal growers, in the form of financial aid of a certain type, but I will wait until the question comes up to go into that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not agree that as far as the feed goes, a serious anomaly exists in areas where farmers who lost their hay crops purchased hay at an inflated price and that is now taken into consideration in the feed voucher? Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I can see the problem there, or rather there could be a problem. I think it was a help but you could not possibly keep tabs of inter-farm sales of hay from one to another and what not. I know some farmers bought hay dear and could not very well afford to do it. It is just not possible to solve a problem of that dimension. I hope, that you did not mind my mentioning a Deputy in your constituency, a Cheann Comhairle.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair keeps repeating that he has no control over the way in which questions are answered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the proposals his Department have made to the European Economic Community regarding the disposal of the co-responsibility fund for Ireland in 1985-86; and if he will recommend that it be made available for the purchase of bulk milk tank refrigerated coolers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: The allocation of the proceeds of the EC co-responsibility levy is a matter for decision by the EC Commission. The measures to be funded during the 1985-86 marketing year have already been agreed. They include a provision of £1.3 million to Ireland for measures to improve milk quality, 40 per cent of which has been allocated for grants to suppliers for the purchase of bulk milk tanks.

I understand that proposals for the allocation of co-responsibility funds for the 1986-87 marketing year are nearing finalisation in the Commission. I have pressed for the continuation of the measures on milk quality improvement which will enable assistance for on-farm refrigerated bulk milk tanks and of a number of other measures of particular interest to Ireland. Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: The Minister said that money would be available from the co-responsibility fund for aiding people going into bulk refrigerated milk.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: Thank you.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
