One company made a submission to the committee and other companies have made submissions to my Department which we have looked at. I think I am right in saying that the Department of Finance is the only Department in the Civil Service that has an experience of charge cards because, as far as I know, it is the only one where we have any number of official charge cards. They are used by a small number of officials who have to travel abroad frequently in the course of their duties and I am bound to say, although I am sure that the gentlemen in question are people who like convenience when travelling, that they do not appear to have made a great deal of use of the cards for a variety of different reasons not the least of which is the fact that they are travelling on fairly well worn tracks and other arrangements have been made to cover the expenditures involved.

I have an open mind on the subject to put it at its most general. There would be a difficulty in relation to the integration or the simultaneous running of the system with the travel and subsistence allowances system that exists under the C and A machinery and I am not quite sure that there would be any very substantial or noticeable gain in convenience to officials on the one hand to set against some possible administrative difficulties on the other hand.

If I may return to the morale question for a moment, I am not 100 per cent convinced by the arguments that the system of charge cards would have a noticeable effect on morale. I do not think it is a matter of trust or anything of that kind. Indeed, I should like to make the point that at one time I had an official credit card that was made available to me by my employer. When I left the employ of that organisation I felt, having used the card quite a bit during my period of employment, that it would not be a bad idea to have one on my own account. As happens in many such cases, I did not do anything about the matter for a while until one day I received a letter of offer from a company that said that I had been picked out of a fairly select group of people in a particular income bracket and that they would be very happy to have me as one of their card holders. Of course, that galvanised me into action again and I said, “That is a good idea; I was intending to do that anyway.” I filled in the form, sent it off and waited for my card to arrive. The next thing that arrived a couple of weeks later was another long and polite letter from the company which said how happy the company were that I had applied to become a card member and asked for my permission, and a date to be fixed, to send an investigator to have a chat with me. That incensed me no end and I wrote back a very rude letter to the company saying that they had picked me, that I had not gone out looking for them and I was not particularly impressed that after they had picked me on the basis of having access to certain confidential information about me they also wanted to send an investigator as well. The moral of the story was that I did not go ahead with that on the basis of that experience.

I am not saying at all that any company would wish to send me a letter now and ask my permission to send an investigator around to the Department of Finance because the probity and rectitude of the Department of Finance, as we heard a few moments ago from the benches opposite, is without question. I will take up the suggestion made by the committee in the spirit in which it is offered. The best response I can make to it is to say that we will monitor the use of the official charge cards that exist in my Department to see whether in that framework any expansion of their use would prove to be of value. We will have to measure the results of that against the system that exists for the handling of travel and subsistence allowances for officials.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: Reading between the lines my impression is that the Minister's mind is not closed to the possibility of looking at the existing charge cards that are used in his Department and, possibly, extending that system. I would be grateful if the Minister would contradict me if I am wrong. I do not know how many such cards there are, or whether the number of cards could be said to constitute a sub-system or not. On the question of morale, I should like to state that none of us is carrying a big flag on that but, regardless of whether it is perceptible or not, it is a reasonable argument and one that has carried weight in the experience of those semi-State agencies here where such cards have been employed. I do not see any reason why it would not have some degree of impact in the same respect for people in the Civil Service.

MainHeading.P: The principal argument we are making is that it may well affect a saving. I do not think it is that important whether the saving is a big or a small one. All these terms are relative. Even the inevitably cautious reply from the Department of Finance to our initial promotings indicated that there could be a saving. I have no doubt with the relatively strapped position of public finances that any saving should be welcomed and that if somebody is willing to say, “Give us 12 months in a fairly closely monitored area of activity and we will try to bring about a saving for you”, that the offer will be taken up and embraced readily in the hope that the target might be overshot.

The Minister referred to the rates for subsistence and travel but, obviously, that is not something we have any view or comment to make on. That is totally outside our jurisdiction and is a matter for the Minister and the conciliation and arbitration scheme. It is not something that our report touches on or something we wish to get involved in. The basic question is the kind of possible savings. Ultimately the reason charge cards and credit cards are becoming more widespread is that areas of the private sector see an advantage in them. I have not adequate experience in that commercial sector to know what those advantages are. I suspect that there are large areas of the public service where such a system would not necessarily be the most appropriate.

I can equally conclude that there must be significant areas of the public service where it would be administratively relatively easy and unquestionably would effect a saving. If charge cards were not working in the private sector we would not be having this discussion. They work because they bring about perceptible advantages. Some of those advantages will undoubtedly accrue in this case if it is given an opportunity. I am sure all Members sympathise with the Minister's bad personal experience related to his initial application and I am mystified as to what might have prompted the scenario of the charge card company sending an investigator to the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dukes Mr. Dukes
Speaker.P: I refused the invitation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: If it is any consolation to the Minister I should like to tell him that a colleague of mine had a similar experience. It turned out that many years ago he had undertaken to take out a subscription to Time magazine and had not paid his dues. I am not suggesting for a moment that anything of such an untoward nature occurred in the Minister's case. I do not know if the card companies will take up the Minister's invitation to send him a letter now because I suspect that the outcome would not be so much that the card company would ask to send an investigator but they might fear that the Minister might send an investigator from the Revenue Commissioners if they were in anyway difficult about it.

The individuals in the card companies with whom the committee and I have had discussions are at the service of the Department. I hope dialogue will ensue and the Minister in his wisdom in due course might come to a judgment which will ensure that the system in his Department in a small way will be extended wherever possible so that any opportunities might be availed of. It works in the semi-State companies and in the American Government. It could work here. What is being said is that a company or companies will sit down with the officials to work out a closely monitored system for a period of time. Administrative costs can be a subject for discussion and negotiation. Certainly, there is bound to be some degree of overlap if two systems are running parallel. Ultimately, there may be benefit in it and we proffer that suggestion in that constructive spirit to the House for further consideration. We are heartened by the fact that the Minister has kept both his mind and the door open to the possibility of development in that respect.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Give it a try, Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: We shall.
Question put and agreed to.
The Dáil adjourned at 9.05 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 27 November, 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware of the decline over the past number of years in agriculture and agri-based exports as a proportion of total gross merchandise exports; and the steps he proposes to take to improve the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The decline in the proportion of total exports which is represented by the agriculture based products reflects the development of the industrial side of the national economy rather than any fall in agricultural based exports as such. In fact, the value of agricultural based exports rose from £1,177 million in 1981 to £1,629 million in 1984, an increase of 38.4 per cent while in volume terms they rose by approximately 12.5 per cent in the same period. In addition, receipts from the FEOGA guarantee section, which are largely dependent on the level of agricultural exports, increased from £305 million in 1981 to £648 million in 1984. The Government policy of encouraging and assisting the expansion of agricultural production as well as achieving a higher level of added value in the food processing industry will further stimulate total receipts from agricultural exports.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the grants available for mountain fencing in this country; whether he has submitted any proposals to the European Economic Community to provide special grant-aid to farmers in the Connemara region for fencing, fertilising and other agricultural activities as promised by his Minister of State in 1984; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Grants of up to 70 per cent of the approved cost are available under the western package for the fencing and improvement of commonage and hill and mountain pastures in the west. Grants of up to 80 per cent of the approved cost are available for work on associated roads. The programme under which the package operates is subject to review at intervals of four years and the first such review is now under way. An announcement will be made when the review has been completed.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if, in view of the implications of the decision for agriculture in the area, and the food industry generally, he will urge Siúicre Éireann cpt to reverse its decision to close the Erin Foods plant in Mallow.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Despite strenuous efforts by the sugar company over a number of years to reverse the fortunes of the Erin Foods operation at Mallow, heavy losses continued to be incurred and were proving to be an unsustainable drain on the company's resources generally. In view of its obligations in respect of its other activities both at Mallow and elsewhere, the company has no alternative other than to decide to close the Mallow plant of Erin Foods at the end of the current season.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McCartin Mr. McCartin
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if it is proposed to reintroduce the western drainage scheme; and, if so, when he hopes to get the new scheme under way.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when the examination regarding the options available for dealing with outstanding applications under the western drainage scheme will be made; the proposals that he has for the future drainage in the west, as promised in June last; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 20 and 185 together. The future of field drainage operations in the west of Ireland is receiving consideration in the context of the review of the western package which is taking place at present. An announcement will be made when the review is completed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware of the crisis situation for tomato growers as a result of the disastrous season just passed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The poor weather conditions this year caused a reduction in tomato crop yields and adversely affected market demand. Steps have been taken already to enable growers to improve their competitiveness. A scheme of grants for the conversion of heating systems from oil to solid fuel was introduced at the beginning of the year and financial aid has also been provided for improved market co-ordination. It is important that growers should avail more fully of these schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason no grants are available for the production, processing and marketing of rabbits.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: A new investment aid scheme to replace the farm modernisation scheme is at present being finalised. It is not possible at this stage to indicate whether aid for rabbit production will be included in this scheme. The availability of aids for the marketing and processing of rabbit meat was dealt with in my reply to a question of 12 March last on that subject.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Foley Mr. Foley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the steps being taken to provide further turbary plots in the north Kerry area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: All usable turbary held by the Land Commission in north Kerry is utilised for local needs. There are no plans to provide further turbary in the area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of the concern regarding the system of assessing applications under the winter food voucher scheme if he will re-examine the guidelines to take into consideration the expenditure incurred by applicants who had bought in winter fodder at inflated prices.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: As already announced, the guidelines for assessing applications under the feed voucher scheme have been re-examined and as a considerable part of the winter fodder purchased by farmers this year has been in the form of straw, I have decided to exclude straw from the calculation of fodder deficiency on farms. This measure should make a substantial contribution to alleviating the problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Foley Mr. Foley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he has any proposals to deal with the serious decline in farmers' incomes especially farmers under the western package scheme; and if he will arrange to make an increased grant under the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The western package is due for review at intervals of four years and the first such review is now proceeding. In light of experience gained since the measure was introduced consideration is being given to changes necessary which will stimulate the development of agriculture in the west. An announcement will follow on completion of the review.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of the huge increase in the export of hay and other fodder to Northern Ireland, despite the claims of a severe fodder crisis, the measures, if any, his Department are taking to ensure that there is no profiteering by farmers who have excess fodder supplies.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of the huge increase in the export of hay and other fodder to Northern Ireland, the measures his Department are taking to ensure that those involved in these exports do not benefit, either directly or indirectly, from the schemes introduced to assist farmers hit by this summer's bad weather.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 26 and 27 together. The schemes which I have introduced to alleviate the problems caused by adverse weather conditions this year are designed to assist those farmers whose fodder situation has been most seriously affected. Only farmers who have less than 75 per cent of their livestock feed requirements qualify for aid under these schemes. Also, the schemes are restricted to those farmers whose main occupation is farming, who have not more than 60 livestock units and who have limited off-farm income. Applications for aid are assessed by the local officers of the farm development service of my Department and they have been instructed to ensure that farmers who sold off fodder do not abuse the schemes. With regard to farmers who have excess supplies of fodder, the only action open to my Department is to exclude such farmers from assistance under the fodder aid schemes, and that is being done.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will bring in amending legislation to discontinue the monopoly enjoyed by the Dublin Milk Board in sales of milk in Dublin city.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The system under which the milk boards operate is currently being examined by the EC Commission. I will be considering the position in the light of the outcome of that examination.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he intends to reintroduce the group fodder scheme in view of the serious difficulties with the saving of fodder this year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The new investment aid scheme to replace the farm modernisation scheme is at present being finalised. It is not possible at this stage to indicate what measures can be provided to encourage the production of high quality fodder but I am very conscious of the need to stimulate the making of silage on a wider scale, particularly in the western region.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is concerned at the apparent increase in farm injuries and fatalities; and if, in conjunction with farming organisations and co-ops, he will initiate a safety campaign directed towards farmers and their families, to deal with this problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The available statistics relate only to fatal farm accidents and these do not show any significant change in recent years. However, this does not mean that every effort should not be made to prevent such accidents. It has long been the policy to promote farm safety through educational, advisory and publicity measures. These activities are now directly implemented by ACOT which emphasises the safety aspect in their courses at agricultural schools and colleges and in their advisory work on the farm.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coogan Mr. Coogan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if his Department will consider any compensatory measures for those farmers who will be forced to retire from pig breeding resulting from the Diseases of Animals (Feeding and Use of Swill) Order, 1985, as many farmers involved in a moderate way with this activity will be unable to meet the capital costs involved in the implementation of the above order.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: There are no funds at my disposal which would enable me to introduce compensatory measures for farmers who might be affected by the provisions of the Diseases of Animals (Feeding and Use of Swill), Order, 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the measures which have been taken by his Department to tackle the high incidence of bovine TB in the many affected areas of County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Having regard to the serious disease situation in a number of areas of County Galway, my Department's veterinary officers have been giving particular attention to the difficulties encountered there in recent months. This attention has taken the form of ongoing intensive testing in the problem areas, specialist advice to herdowners and active investigation of the role of wildlife. There have been signs of improvement recently in the disease situation in County Galway and it is hoped that further progress can be achieved through intensive testing and continuing co-operation and involvement by farmers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Local Appointments Commission Advertisments.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the reason salaries for public positions are no longer placed in advertisements placed by the Local Appointments Commission.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The practice of omitting salary scales in advertisements placed by the Local Appointments Commission was adopted by the commissioners in an effort to control expenditure on advertising. The majority of vacancies being advertised are similar posts under the various local authorities or health boards; the approximate level of salary is known to the people who are interested; candidatures are satisfactory and full details of the salary scale are given in the documentation issued to intending applicants.

Where the post being advertised is a new type of one or where the status of the post may not be clear it is the practice to quote the minimum and maximum points of the salary scale. Employing authorities are satisfied with these arrangements. A similar practice operates in relation to advertisements placed by the Civil Service Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism the reason for the continuing increase in insurance cover for motor cycles, in view of the fact that insurance companies only cover third party, which limits claims.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: As with other types of insurance cover, increase in premium rates for motor cycle insurance reflect the continuing and substantial level of losses incurred by insurers providing this particular insurance.

It is not correct to say that insurers only provide third party cover for motor cycle risks, since comprehensive cover is also available. However, even in the case of a policy restricted to third party cover this does not of itself limit claims, because, under road traffic law, the cover granted for personal injuries must be unlimited.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Job Creation Evaluation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism in view of the substantial national resources allocated to the jobcreating activities of the various State agencies, if he considers it is necessary to evaluate accurately the cost of creating a job so as to ascertain that the State receives the best return possible on its investment; and if he will take steps to have an accurate calculation made within his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: I share the Deputy's concern that we should accurately evaluate the cost of creating a job in manufacturing industry and I am happy to inform him that my Department, in consultation with the management committee on industrial policy, are drawing up a uniform basis for computing cost per job, which, I expect, will be agreed within the next six weeks. When drawing up cost per job figures care must be taken to define what precisely is being measured. A number of first time jobs created in any year arise from grant payments in previous years. Similarly grant payments made in any one year will give rise to new first time jobs in succeeding years.

It might not be prudent to pre-determine a cost per direct job above which one would not go in supporting a project. There is another factor, namely, the indirect employment associated with the project, arising from the further investment of the value added generated by the sourcing of raw material requirements in Ireland, which must be taken into account. Every effort must, of course, also be made to quantify such indirect jobs although the figures will be somewhat more difficult to determine.

MainHeading.P: The overall targets set for job creation in the White Paper on Industrial Policy is the growth of manufacturing employment of between 3,000 and 6,000 jobs per year. This is a very ambitious target in the light of past trends here and in other countries. All Government agencies concerned with manufacturing, whether in the investment, export or technical support areas, are being required to use their resources in such a way as to jointly assure the achievement of these targets over the ten year period of application of the White Paper.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Development of Small Business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism if he accepts that franchising offers potential for development particularly in the area of generating small business; and if he will outline the measures, if any, he intends to take to encourage franchising.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: The franchise system is of particular significance in the retail sector, where we have seen in recent years a substantial growth in the number of new outlets being operated under franchise. Save for compliance, as appropriate, with planning legislation etc., there are no restrictions on the development of this system of trading and I do not consider that there is any need to devise an action programme to encourage it. Of course where such a system could be used in the promotion of exports of goods or services it will be actively supported. Any suggestion the Deputy wishes to make in this regard will be carefully studied.

In so far as manufacturing is concerned, the Industrial Development Authority are actively promoting the use of joint ventures, licensing and technology acquisition among Irish manufacturing firms as a means of developing their business. The upgrading of the teachnical expertise of domestic companies is a key objective of the White Paper on Industrial Policy, published in July 1984.

In 1984 the IDA intensified their strategy of using their network of overseas offices to work with Irish firms seeking licences and joint ventures. Recent progress in this area was set out in my reply to a question by the Deputy relating to technology acquisition grants on 31 October 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism given the need to develop flexible structures to revive ailing companies with trading and financial difficulties highlighted in the recent annual report of Fóir Teoranta, if he considers it would be appropriate to initiate reform in this area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: I am in broad agreement with the views on company rescue expressed in Fóir Teoranta's annual report for the year ended 31 December 1984, and have myself discussed the matter with the then chairman of the company. Officials in my Department are already carrying out an intensive examination of the conditions and structures necessary to facilitate company rescue with a view to the formulation of proposals for legal reform in this area. Appropriate provisions of company law in other countries are being studied in the course of this examination.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Water Pollution.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Department or the health board have responsibility to ensure the quality of water provided for group schemes; the body who are obliged to notify the members of the group scheme where pollution occurs; and the financial assistance, if any, which is available to clean up pollution.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: A group water scheme which is not taken in charge by the sanitary authority remains in the ownership of the members who would have responsibilities in relation to the maintenance of the quality of the water and the issue of warnings if the supply becomes polluted. The local sanitary authority must be satisfied that the proposed source for a group water supply scheme is suitable and adequate for domestic and other use before grants are allocated to enable a scheme to proceed.

MainHeading.P: Sanitary authorities have certain general responsibilities under the terms of EC Directive 1820/80 relating to the quality of water intended for human consumption, in regard to the monitoring of the quality of both public and private drinking water supplies in their areas. Where sanitary authorities become aware that a supply whether public or private is unfit for human consumption, they have a duty to take all reasonable steps to warn users.

There is provision whereby my Department can pay second grants for capital works to remedy a seriously deficient water supply in an existing group scheme. Sanitary authorities can also carry out themselves or, with my consent under section 26 of the 1948 Act, can assist in the provision, improvement or maintenance of any water supply other than a public water supply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will allocate a substantial increase in the block grant to Kerry County Council in 1986 for the improvement of the county roads which have deteriorated considerably in recent years; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The block grant allocations to individual local authorities for 1986 will be determined following the settlement of the budgetary provision for road grants for 1986. Primary responsibility for the planning and execution of improvement works on county roads rests with the local authorities. The expenditure involved falls to be financed by the local authorities from their own resources which may be supplemented by the block grant for roads paid annually by my Department. The block grant may also be used, in the case of county councils, for the improvement, maintenance and management of non-national main roads and for the implementation of traffic management measures. The disposition of the block grant, including the extent, if any, to which it is to be applied to improvement works on county roads, is a matter entirely for each local authority.

This year, the block grant allocation to local authorities was increased by 10 per cent compared with 1984. Earlier this year, I announced that a grant of up to 75 per cent of the cost will be paid towards the cost of approved improvement works on the more important county road bridges, with a view to the preservation of the county road network.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: At the Council of Fisheries Ministers held on 4 November 1985 the question of fishing controls was discussed in the context both of a Commission proposal on measures to be adopted to tighten controls under the existing Common Fishing Policy and of the impending accession of Spain and Portugal. I agree with the Deputy that more thorough policing of Community waters will act as a deterrent to illegal fishing in Irish waters.

MainHeading.P: 106. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McGinley Mr. McGinley
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cad atá socraithe ag Údarás na Gaeltachta a dhéanamh le monarcha GT ar an Eastát Tionscail i nGaoth Dobhair; agus cad é costas measta na hoibre.

Speaker.hpid: Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole) Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: Tógfaidh mé ceisteanna Uimh. 105 agus 106 le chéile. Tuigim ó Údarás na Gaeltachta

—go bhfuil obair athchóirithe á déanamh ar an mhonaracha mhór sin faoi láthair i gcaoi go mbeidh 12 aonad tionsclaíochta ar leith ann mar aon leis an spás atá in úsáid mar stór ag fochuideachta atá lonnaithe ar an Eastát,
—go meastar go mbeidh an chuid is mó den obair críochnaithe faoi dheireadh na bliana,

—go bhfuil tograí á bplé do dhá aonad,

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if it has been decided or if it is possible for the proceeds of the National Lottery to be allocated to recreational and sporting facilities such as swimming pools, as there is no Department of State which currently gives direct grant aid for such facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The Government have decided that funds from the proposed National Lottery are to be allocated inter alia to recreational and sporting facilities. It should be noted that three Departments of State are at present engaged in the provision of financial assistance for sports organisations or for sporting and recreational facilities. The Department of the Environment operates a loan subsidy scheme for local authorities which provide local authority swimming pools or which provide financial assistance to voluntary or other organisations for the construction of swimming pools. The Department of Labour operates a grant scheme (i) for the construction of indoor recreational facilities other than swimming pools by organisations which wish to improve the recreational environment and (ii) for the improvement of their facilities by youth organisations. The Department of Education provides assistance for the general expenses of sports organisations and for miscellaneous sporting activities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance in view of the international expert and academic opinion that exchange controls are largely ineffective and the general overseas moves towards a relaxation of exchange controls, if he will give serious consideration to liberalising Irish exchange control laws; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The exchange controls are intended to help safeguard the external reserves and to regulate the effects of capital movements on the Irish pound in the EMS framework. The operation of the controls is kept under regular review by my Department and the Central Bank and relaxations are introduced where possible. However, our still large balance of payments deficit and high external indebtedness do not suggest that there is any scope at present for significant new relaxations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Dea Mr. O'Dea
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the up-to-date position in respect of the application of a person (details supplied) in County Limerick for retirement pension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned submitted a claim for a retirement pension on 23 October 1985. One of the qualifying conditions for receipt of this pension requires a person to have a yearly average of at least 24 reckonable contributions over the period from the beginning of the 1953 contribution year or from his year of entry into insurance, whichever is the later, to the end of the last complete contribution year before reaching pension age. The Department's records show that the person concerned had a total of 188 reckonable contributions in the relevant period which, in his case, is from 5 January 1953 to 5 April 1985. This is equal to a yearly average of only five and he does not, therefore, qualify for a retirement pension. Neither will he qualify for an old age contributory pension at age 66; a yearly average of at least 20 is required for this latter pension. Depending on his means, he may qualify for an old age non-contributory pension when he reaches age 66 on 24 October 1986. A claim form for a non-contributory pension can be obtained at any post office and should be submitted to the Department approximately four months before he reaches age 66.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Invalidity pension is payable in place of disability benefit to insured persons who satisfy the contribution conditions and who are permanently incapable of work. The person concerned claimed disability benefit from 18 October 1980. He is not qualified for benefit as regulations provide that where a claimant has no contributions paid or credited for any two consecutive contribution years preceding his claim, he cannot qualify for payment of disability benefit, or the award of credited contributions in respect of periods of incapacity for work, until he has a further 26 weeks of insurable employment for which the appropriate contributions have been paid.

According to the records of the Department, the person concerned had less than 156 contributions paid. He also has no contributions paid or credited in the years 1972 and 1973 and has not had 26 weeks of insurable imployment since then. Accordingly, he cannot be considered for disability benefit, invalidity pension or for the award of credited contributions in respect of unemployment or incapacity for work.
He is presently in receipt of supplementary welfare allowance from the South Eastern Health Board at the weekly rate of £31.80.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The EC Regulations on Social Security for migrant workers is applicable to persons claiming benefit who work and travel between all member states. Accordingly the same provisions apply to an applicant for benefit between this country and Belgium as would apply between this country and the United Kingdom.

The person concerned applied for unemployment benefit and in accordance with the relevant EC Regulation her entitlement for benefit was transferred to this country with effect from 1 October 1985 and she is at present in receipt of weekly payment at £83.64. Subject to her satisfying the requirements of remaining unemployed and being available for but continue to be paid unemployment benefit until 31 December 1985 when she is due to exhaust her entitlement. If she remains unemployed and available for work after 31 December 1985 she would be entitled to claim unemployment assistance subject to her being the holder of a qualification certificate. She has already applied for a qualification certificate and her case is at present being investigated after which her entitlement to unemployment assistance from 1 January 1986 will be determined in the light of the outcome of the inquiries.

She has been furnished with an application from to enable her to claim deserted wives benefit or allowance which she should complete and return to this Department. If she requires any further information about her entitlements the manager at her local branch employment office will be pleased to discuss and advise her on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the present position with regard to an application for unemployment assistance from a person (details supplied) in County Galway; the reason he has had no communication from his Department and no call from a social welfare officer since he commenced signing the unemployment register in May; when it is expected that a decision will be taken on this application; and if he will inform Deputy Frank Fahey of the decision.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed unemployment assistance but his claim was disallowed on the grounds that his means derived from the profit from his holding exceeded the statutory limit. He made a repeat application in May 1985. Due to the increased number of persons applying for various means tested social welfare services, there is an inevitable lengthening of the time taken in investigating cases and in this situation, repeat claims are not accorded the same priority as fresh applications.

The papers in this case were referred to the social welfare officer to carry out an investigation into the means of the person concerned and arrangements have been made to make the necessary inquiries, shortly. The entitlement of the person concerned to unemployment assistance will then be determined in the light of the means assessed against him, and he will be informed of the decision. The delay in this case is regretted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when full children's allowance including arrears will be paid in respect of a child (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Children's allowance was paid to the claimant in respect of the child in question up to and including June 1985. An application for a further continuation of the allowance was received on 4 November 1985. Children's allowance has been awarded in respect of the child for the period July to December 1985 and an allowance book was issued direct to the claimant's home address on 18 November 1985. As the child in question reaches 18 years of age in December 1985 no further allowance is payable after that date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Crowley Mr. Crowley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason arrears of an invalidity pension which has been approved for a person (details supplied) in County Cork have not been paid from 12 July 1985 when he submitted his application.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Invalidity pension is payable to insured persons who satisfy the contribution conditions and who are permanently incapable of work. A deciding officer decided that she was not therefore entitled to invalidity pension. However arrangements are being made to have her examined by a different medical referee. Her entitlement to invalidity pension will be further considered in the light of this report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the present position in relation to his recommendation to the Cabinet that a pensions board be set up to regulate occupational pension schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the up-to-date position in relation to the long delay in the consideration of the unemployment assistance appeal of a person (details supplied) in County Kerry; and if he will give an indication as to when the appeal will be decided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The appeal of the person concerned was determined on 15 November 1985 and his means, derived from the profit from his holding which had been assessed at £73.05 weekly, were assessed at £63.45 weekly, effective from 23 January 1985. He is accordingly entitled, from 23 January 1985, to adjusting arrears of £9.60 weekly which will be paid to him this week and weekly payments of £21.20, being the appropriate rate in his case of £84.65 less means of £63.45, will continue to be made as they become due.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when an appeal for disability benefit will be heard for a person (details supplied) in County Carlow.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned was paid disability benefit to 29 August 1985 after which date payment was disallowed following an examination by a medical referee who expressed the opinion that he was capable of work. He appealed against the disallowance of benefit and was examined by a different medical referee who also expressed the opinion that he was capable of work. His case has been referred to an appeals officer who proposes to hold an oral hearing of his claim as soon as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Prendergast Mr. Prendergast
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for the refusal of his Department to pay disability benefit to a person (details supplied) in County Limerick as she has been sending in medical certificates since 1978 and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Where a person has less than 156 contributions paid since entry into insurable employment, entitlement to disability benefit is limited to 52 weeks. According to the records of the Department the person concerned has only 90 contributions paid on her behalf since entry into insurance. She claimed disability benefit from 29 April 1983 to 6 July 1983 and from 2 August 1983 to date. Her 52 week entitlement to payment of benefit became exhausted on 29 May 1984. In order to requalify for disability benefit it will be necessary for her to have at least a further 13 weeks of insurable employment for which the appropriate contributions are paid.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will arrange to pay unemployment benefit to a person (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Entitlement to unemployment benefit is subject to the condition that a claimant must have at least 26 contributions paid at a class which provides cover against unemployment. According to the Department's records the person concerned entered insurable employment on 2 December 1983 and has only 14 contributions at the appropriate class paid on her behalf up to the date she claimed unemployment benefit on 26 August 1985. However, inquiries are being made to establish whether her employment with the Southern Health Board from June 1984 to May 1985 was insurable at a contribution class providing cover against unemployment. Her entitlement to unemployment benefit will be determined in the light of the outcome of this investigation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare whether pay-related unemployment benefit is still due to a person (details supplied) in County Kerry arising from his redundancy from his previous employment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Entitlement to pay-related benefit with flat rate unemployment benefit is subject to the condition that the weekly sum of pay-related benefit, flat rate unemployment benefit and income tax rebate may not exceed 85 per cent of the net average weekly earnings of a claimant.

The person concerned claimed unemployment benefit on 2 December 1978 and payment of flat rate unemployment benefit was made at the weekly rate of £49 being the maximum rate appropriate to a married man with seven child dependants. The 85 per cent limit applicable to him was calculated at £44.24 and as the rate of flat rate unemployment benefit exceeded this figure no pay-related benefit was payable. He continued to sign as unemployed and he exhausted his entitlement to unemployment benefit on 4 March 1980. He then claimed unemployment assistance and was in receipt of payment until 27 April 1985 when he returned to work.

MainHeading.P: He made a repeat application for unemployment benefit on 9 September 1985 and re-qualified for a further period of unemployment benefit. Payment was made at the weekly rate of £111.10, being the appropriate maximum rate payable to a married man with five child dependants. Weekly payments will continue as they become due. The person concerned is not entitled to pay-related benefit as he had no earnings in the relevant income tax period 6 April 1983 to 5 April 1984 which determined entitlement on his current claim.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carey Mr. Carey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason a person (details supplied) in County Clare is not being paid unemployment benefit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Entitlement to unemployment benefit is subject to the condition that a person must have at least 26 contributions, paid or credited, in the governing contribution year. The person concerned claimed unemployment benefit on 20 August 1985. Inquiries were necessary to establish whether he fulfilled the condition of having 26 contributions paid or credited in the relevant period 6 April 1983 to 5 April 1984. These inquiries were recently completed and his claim was allowed at the appropriate weekly rate in his case of £39.50. Arrears of £506.95 due to him were paid on 22 November 1985 and further weekly payments of £39.50 will continue to be made as they become due.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The person concerned is in receipt of a teacher's retirement pension from the Department of Education, which is not a qualifying payment under the free schemes. The allowances referred to by the Deputy cannot therefore be granted in this case.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason a children's allowance book belonging to a person (details supplied) in County Cork which was returned to his Department at its request three weeks ago was not returned yet; and when it will be reissued.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The allowance book in question, which was recalled for inspection, has been returned to the claimant. Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan

He will be paid his cattle headage grant under the 1985 disadvantaged areas schemes and his calf premium as soon as the batches which include his payments are processed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he considers that the suggestion recently put forward at the National Co-operative Conference that the problem of the EC butter mountain might be alleviated by transforming the butter surplus into animal feed over the period of a two to three year programme merits consideration; and if he will approve such a course of action to improve the climate of the commercial market.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The reduction of the large EC stock of the invention butter will require a series of disposal measures on both the internal and external markets. A number of such measures are already in operation and I understand that further schemes, including the incorporation of intervention butter in animal feed, are under consideration by the EC Commission.
I have consistently pressed for an effective disposal policy; however, the introduction of specific measures is a matter for the EC Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture in view of its very grave implications for the development of the dairy industry, if he considers that it is appropriate to seek a derogation for this country from the proposed milk cessation scheme: and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: In the negotiations on this scheme my objective will be to achieve the best possible result for the Irish milk industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he has made representations to the EC in relation to the allegations by the Canadian Cattlemen's Association that beef imports from EC countries are undercutting Canadian meat prices, which accusations may damage the valuable Irish beef export trade to Canada; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Both I and my Department have been in touch with the EC Commission about this matter. The Commission is actively pursuing it both in the GATT and direct with the Canadian authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is concerned at the number of persons serving prison terms of non-payment of fines when it is costing far more than the actual fine to keep these people in prison; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East)
Speaker.P: The courts must have available means of ensuring that court orders, whether in relation to fines or any other matter, are obeyed. At present imprisonment is imposed as a sanction when fines remain unpaid. The Whitaker Committee made certain recommendations regarding seizure of property etc. in lieu of unpaid fines. As with other recommendations of that committee these are being examined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when tenders will be invited for improvement works at St. Colman's national school, Corofin, County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: It is expected that the contract documents for the proposed extension to St. Colman's national school, Corofin, County Galway, will be completed in a few weeks time. The question of invitation of tenders will then be considered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her Department will sanction the required extension to Kilkerley national school, County Louth; and if so when work will start.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Following the grant-aiding by my Department of a new school comprising four classrooms and a general purposes room for Kilkerley national school, County Louth, the school authorities applied for aid to provide a fifth classroom. My Department, following examination of the matter, has informed the school authorities that it is satisfied that the recently provided accommodation, will be adequate for the school's immediate needs and that, because of the difficult financial climate at present, it would not be in question to provide additional permanent accommodation before it is seen to be actually required in the long term, It is not therefore proposed to sanction a grant for an extension. The matter will however be kept under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will arrange for school transport to be supplied to twelve children from the townlands of Ballyavil, Ballylevin and Ard, Geashill, County Offaly, to Geashill national school, County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I understand that an application for school transport for twelve children from the townlands in question was received by CIE on Wendnesday last. The question of establishing a transport service from these townlands will be investigated. I will let the Deputy know the outcome.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will approve the provision of a regional technical college in Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The national plan Building on Reality 1984-1987 outlines at paragraph 7.85 the priorities in regard to additional provision in the third level sector. These do not include the provision of a regional technical college in Monaghan and no such proposal has been made to my Department. In this connection it should be noted that the regional technical colleges were established to serve designated regions, each region comprising a number of counties or parts thereof. County Monaghan is served by Dundalk Regional Technical College. There would not appear to be a substantiated case for a regional technical college in Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Dea Mr. O'Dea
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the progress which has been made in relation to an application for a 16 teacher school at Milford Grange, Castletroy, Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department awaits a report from its inspectorate as to the present and longer term needs of the Milford Grange national school, Castletory, Limerick in terms of permanent accommodation, and will communicate with the school authorities as soon as this has been established with a view to the commencement of architectural planning. A site has been offered by the school authorities which, while generally suitable for building, has been found to be somewhat below the area stipulated for a 16 classroom school in the Department's planning data.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when it is anticipated that tenders will be invited for national schools (details supplied) in County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of objections by parents of pupils attending Kenmare vocational school, County Kerry, to the proposed community school in Kenmare; and if she will make a statement on the matter, indicating her proposals for a suitable building to accommodate this proposed community school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I am aware of the objections referred to by the Deputy. However I wish to reassure the parents that when the major building project which will be undertaken at the Holy Cross secondary school is completed, Kenmare will have a first class school facility for all its post primpary pupils.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if a caretaker and school secretary can be approved for Deansrath primary school, Clondalkin, County Dublin, in view of the urgent need for the services at the school and having regard to the fact that the National Manpower Service approved such posts under the social employment scheme but applicants under that scheme were not forthcoming.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: In accordance with the Government decision to phase out the schemes for the employment of caretakers in national schools and clerk-typists in national and secondary schools, it is not open to my Department to approve the appointment of a clerk-typist and caretaker for Deansrath national school. The operation of the social employment scheme is a matter for the Department of Labour. I understand, however, that under the scheme, a caretaker has recently been appointed to Deansrath national school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the concern of, and hardship endured by, grantaided pupils whether that be county council or VEC, because of the delay in payment of such grants some of which have not been paid to date; if she will ensure that such grants will be paid immediately and in future that they will be paid in the first month of each term, thus ensuring that all such pupils can continue their education; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The administration of the higher education grants and the VEC scholarships schemes have been statutorily entrusted to the local rating authorities and the vocational education committees respectively. The speciman higher education grants scheme issued by my Department to the local authorities each year contains a provision as follows:—

“Every effort will be made by the ...County Council-Corporation...to pay the maintenance element (if any) of a grant-holder's grant in three equal instalments, one as early as possible in each term, and the individual paying orders will be addressed to the grant-holders c/o the bursar's office of the university or other educational institution concerned”.

A similar provision is contained in the specimen vocational education committee scholarship's scheme issued annually by the Department to each committee. It is a matter for each local authority and vocational education committee to apply these provisions in its functional area and I would be concerned if there was any undue delay in the payment of grants or scholarships to students.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Wexford Vocational Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the urgent need for playing facilities to complement Kilmuckridge vocational school and that land is available adjacent to the school; if she will give approval to Wexford VEC for the purchase of this land as it is unlikely that any such parcel of land will ever become available again; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

It is not open to my Department to agree to a price in excess of that advised by the Valuation Office.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the terrible condition of prefabs being used as classrooms in Adamstown vocational school, County Wexford, and of the conditions being endured by the teachers and pupils of that school; if she will immediately sanction the start of the school; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the confusion created by her Department in relation to the location of the proposed new vocational school at Gorey, County Wexford; if she will ensure that the school will be built on a suitable site with adequate facilities for future expansion and for playing facilities; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department's position is, and has been, that the proposed new vocational school at Gorey will form part of the second level school complex to be built on the Loreto school site. Architectural planning of the complex commenced recently at a briefing session between officials of my Department, the school authorities and their consultants. The first stage of the planning procedures relates to site suitability and my Department awaits the consultants' report on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the cramped conditions endured by teachers and pupils in Bunclody vocational school, County Wexford; and when she will grant permission to Wexford County Vocational Education Committee to go to tender; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The planning of the proposed extension to Bunclody vocational school has reached the stage where amended bills of quantities (which included extensive revision) and tender documents have been received from the County Wexford Vocational Education Committee recently and are currently under examination in the Department. When this examination has been completed the Department will be in touch with the vocational education committee. Pending completion of this examination, I am not in a position to say when this project may proceed to tender.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will sanction the provision of a remedial teacher for the schools in Kilkee, County Clare; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Applications for schools for remedial posts are processed by my Department's inspectorate and available posts are allocated in accordance with a priority of need. The application of the schools referred to by the Deputy has not, to date, been placed sufficiently high in order of priority of educational need to warrant the allocation of a post. The application will, however, be further considered in the light of the availability of such posts in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will provide school transport for a pupil (details supplied) in County Roscommon.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The pupil in question is not eligible for free school transport under the terms of the school transport scheme since he resides less than two miles from his nearest school. The school referred to by the Deputy is not the nearest school to the pupil and it is not open to my Department to provide transport facilities for the pupil, whether free or fare paying, to that school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up to date position regarding the proposed all-Irish school at Rathcoole, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: A contract has been entered into for the purchase of an access route to the site for the proposed all-Irish school at Rathcoole, County Dublin. The Chief State Solicitor's Office is at present attending to the completion of the transactions with a view to my Department being able to invite tenders for the project.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the reason a person (details supplied) in County Cavan received no redundancy payment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I understand that the person concerned, who was temporarily laid off work some months ago, applied to his employer for payment of a statutory redundancy lump sum but that the employer served counter-notice under the Redundancy Payments Acts that work was available for the employee and that he should return to his employment. If the person concerned considers that he is entitled to a statutory redundancy lump sum payment and this is disputed by his employer, the only way open to him to establish his entitlement is by appealing to the Employment Appeals Tribunal for a determination of his case. In case he wishes to pursue this course, I am sending the Deputy the appropriate form for an appeal to the tribunal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when redundancy money will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: My Department has no record of a claim for payment of a redundancy lump sum in respect of the person concerned. I should explain, in any event, that an employer is responsible in the first instance for the payment of a statutory redundancy lump sum and that if an employee has not received such payment or a redundancy certificate (form RP2), he should claim payment of the lump sum by serving form RP77 on his employer. If the employer gives the employee a redundancy certificate but refuses to pay him a statutory redundancy lump sum, the employee should complete form RP14 and send it, together with the redundancy certificate, to my Department so as to claim payment from the Redundancy and Employers' Insolvency Fund. However, if the employer fails or refuses to pay a redundancy lump sum or to issue a redundancy certificate, the only way open to an employee to establish entitlement to payment of a statutory redundancy lump sum is by appealing to the Employment Appeals Tribunal for a determination of his case. In order to enable the person concerned here to pursue his claim, my Department has already sent the Deputy the appropriate forms.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is aware of the need for the attendance of a national manpower service officer on one day a week in Rathdowney, County Laois as the people in this town have to travel over 24 miles to the nearest national manpower service office; if he will consider allowing a national manpower service officer to attend in Rathdowney at least once a week and if he will outline the position herein.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: At present a placement officer from the National Manpower Service operates from the employment exchange in Rathdowney twice a month. In the context of development of the National Manpower Service, I am, however, considering the provision of a clinic in the town on a twice-monthly basis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when a redundancy payment will be made to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: My Department has not received an application for payment of a statutory redundancy lump sum to the person concerned. I understand, in any event, that she had less than two years service with the company by which she was employed and would not, therefore, be entitled to payment of a lump sum under the Redundancy Payments Acts. I understand, however, that the person concerned has been awarded payment in lieu of minimum notice by the Employment Appeals Tribunal. In order to claim that payment, she should complete form IP2, which has been sent to her by the tribunal, and submit it to the receiver of the company who will then apply to my Department for funds to pay the minimum notice award. As soon as the application is received through the receiver, it will be dealt with without delay by the Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when a redundancy payment will be made to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The person concerned will be paid his statutory redundancy lump sum entitlement from the Redundancy and Employers' Insolvency Fund within the next few days.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when a person (details supplied) in County Kerry will receive his statutory redundancy money which he claimed on 16 August 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The person concerned was paid his full statutory lump sum entitlement from the Redundancy and Employers' Insolvency Fund on 23 October 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Foley Mr. Foley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will arrange to pay the application for entitlements under the Protection of Employees (Employers' Insolvency) Act, 1984, to a person (details supplied) in County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The person concerned is claiming payment from the Redundancy and Employers' Insolvency Fund of outstanding wages, holiday pay and a minimum notice award by the Employment Appeals Tribunal on the basis of the insolvency of the company. My Department is investigating the circumstances of the closure of the company in order to establish whether it can be deemed to be insolvent for the purposes of the Protection of Employees (Employers' Insolvency) Act, 1984. These investigations will require some time to complete and may involve the making of a statutory instrument. If the investigations show that the company is insolvent for the purposes of the Act, the claims of the person concerned will be processed without delay by the Department.
